byline.contributor: Jodi Rudoren reported from Jerusalem, and Julie Hirschfeld Davis from Washington. Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker contributed reporting from Washington.
byline.original: By JODI RUDOREN and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu apologizes to Israeli Arabs for comments made in final stretch of election campaign about Arab citizens voting in 'droves,' which were widely condemned as racist; Denis McDonough, chief of staff to Pres Obama, suggests that administration remains furious over Netanyahu's campaign comments seeming to reject possibility of Palestinian state.
lead_paragraph: Despite an apology by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the White House remained furious about comments that appeared to close the door on a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict.

headline.main: Netanyahu Apologizes; White House Is Unmoved
headline.print_headline: Netanyahu Apologizes; White House Is Unmoved

snippet: Despite an apology by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the White House remained furious about comments that appeared to close the door on a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict.
